results.title: The Cat who drank and used too much
results.creator_credit: Timothy Armstrong, Randall Frederick, Yvonne Parsons and FMS Productions
results.brief_description: Featuring Pat the Cat, this rather clever film produced by the US Alcohol and Drug Foundation focuses on the damage caused by excess drinking and the availability of help and support through the Recovery Center. Pat the Cat starts drinking to excess, tries other substances, ignores his friends’ advice, crashes his car and is finally referred for recovery. Narrated by Julie Harris.

results.title: H.M.A.S. Voyager: the cruel legacy
results.creator_credit: Harvey Broadbent and Australian Broadcasting Corporation
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Four corners (Television program)”.
On February 10th, 1964, the destroyer HMAS Voyager was sliced in two when it collided with her flagship aircraft carrier HMAS Melbourne in Jervis Bay, off the coast of New South Wales. Voyager sunk with the loss of 82 men. This program attempts to piece together the final minutes before the fatal collision and the years of bitter neglect for the survivors of Voyager who are still fighting for justice and compensation. Their burden has been one of broken careers, sometimes broken marriages and often broken mental and physical health. Although two Royal Commissions have taken place, responsibility for the collision still remains unanswered, counselling and support have never been provided to the survivors and a certain amount of suspicion still exists about high-ranking naval personnel cover-ups. Reporter: Andrew Olle.

results.title: Go to jail
results.creator_credit: Lin Buckfield and Australian Broadcasting Corporation
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Four corners (Television program)”.
This program discusses the impacts of decisions by the Northern Territory and Western Australian governments to introduce mandatory sentencing for juveniles. The laws have caused a storm of protest from civil rights advocates who view mandatory sentencing as an attack on young Aboriginals, who make up over 70 percent of people charged with offences in the Northern Territory. The fact that trivial and first offenders are punished by jail terms is the main driver of discontent. Acknowledgement is made that mandatory sentencing does not work, that there is a high amount of recidivism and that it can be the cause of deaths in custody. Includes interviews with members of the Aboriginal communities, magistrates, prison officers and Hazel Lallara, the grandmother of a 15 year-old who hanged himself whilst in custody. Reporter: Liz Jackson.

results.title: The Cat came back
results.creator_credit: Cordell Barker, Ches Yetman, Richard Condie and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description: Cordell Barker’s animated film is based on a century old folk song. Poor old Mr Johnson becomes increasingly manic as he tries and tries again to rid himself of a little yellow cat. His desperate attempts to find solitude become an obsession, with tragic consequences. Winner of the Special Jury Prize for Humor and Music at the 1988 World Festival of Animation in Zagreb. Fourteen awards, including Chicago; Shanghai; Quebec; Genie, Toronto; Oscar nomination.

results.title: Escape to nowhere
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Four corners (Television program)”.
Surveys the general problem of drug abuse in Australia, pointing out the extent of dependence on alcohol, tobacco and various pharmaceutical preparations and the damage resulting from them as well as the use of illegal narcotics and hallucinogens

results.title: The Dole Generation
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Four corners (Television program)”.
Two items from the Four Corners television program. “The Dole Generation” looks at the frustration’s of the unemployed and some community work-schemes operating in Adelaide for young people. ‘Russian Nuclear accident’ traces the clues that makes Dr Zhores Meduedev, an exiled Soviet biochemist, believe that stored nuclear waste accidentally exploded in the Ural mountains of Russia in 1957, killing several thousand people

results.title: Computers
results.creator_credit: David Stiven, Sam Lipski and ABC-TV (Australia)
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Four corners (Television program)”.
Discusses the devleopment and increasing use of computers in Australia. Banks, the TAB, the stock exchange, aviation companies and many government social service departments are extensively computerised. Computers have an invaluable application in medical research and hospital services, and road traffic control. Presents the problem of redundant workers in a computerised community and questions the morality of a National Data Bank.

results.title: Cancer
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Four corners (Television program)”.
Discusses the nature of cancer cells, and how they are identified. Stresses the importance of early diagnosis and prompt treatment in the cure of many cases. Shows the method of self-examination of the breasts; emphasises the need for women to have regular cell tests for uterine cancer; and the value of regular chest X-rays. Shows the work done by the Anti-Cancer Council of Victoria, the Cytology Service at Prince Henry’s Hospital and the Peter MacCallum Clinic.
results.description:
Episode of Series “Four corners (Television program)”.
Discusses the nature of cancer cells, and how they are identified. Stresses the importance of early diagnosis and prompt treatment in the cure of many cases. Shows the method of self-examination of the breasts; emphasises the need for women to have regular cell tests for uterine cancer; and the value of regular chest X-rays. Shows the work done by the Anti-Cancer Council of Victoria, the Cytology Service at Prince Henry’s Hospital and the Peter MacCallum Clinic.

results.title: The Business of change
results.creator_credit: Francoise Fombertaux and Australian Broadcasting Corporation
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Four corners (Television program)”.
Change, particularly technological change, has become an unavoidable facet of daily life. In this changing world of work, to accept change has become a business - “being motivated to be motivated”. Teaching “change” is the new profession and trained psychologists are now moving into the area of business coaching - they are the highly skilled agents of change. Manufacturing and agricultural industries have decreased and have been replaced by the service industry which currently employs over 70% of the entire workforce in Australia. Professional people who have more money than time are increasingly outsourcing services, eg house maintenance and cleaning, pet care (professional dog walkers). Corporate, big business, and government agencies use Call Centres to centralise their customer service facilities. This program discusses motivational coaching as a means of helping people deal with change. Reference is also made to Frederick W. Taylor’s theory on organisational change, or Taylorism. Reporter: Tony Barrell.
